item.description:
Hike the Blue Hills Skyline Trail!

Considered one of the most beautiful hikes in the most scenic natural area around Boston, the Skyline Trail in the Blue Hills Reservation provides stunning views in all directions, not least of which is the panorama of Boston's skyline.

   The Blue Hills lie just south of Boston, only 1hr. 20min. from Portsmouth.

Blue Hills Reservation is a 7,000-acre natural area perfect for hiking, mountain biking, skiing, rock climbing, and horseback riding.

Great Blue Hill, the park's highest point, is the site of an historic weather station. The Blue Hill Meteorological Observatory was founded in 1885. It's the oldest continuous weather recording station in the United States. Hikers can climb the observatory's tower for views of Boston and the surrounding countryside.

The ecology of the Blue Hills is diverse and includes marshes, swamps, upland & bottom land forests, meadows, and an Atlantic White Cedar bog.

A number of endangered species in Massachusetts, such as the timber rattlesnake, reside in the reservation. There are also lady's slipper, coyotes, and numerous birds of prey.

 

The Massachusetts Audubon Society runs the Trailside Museum, which includes indoor and outdoor LIVE animal exhibits.

Located a few miles from downtown Boston, the reservation has the distinction of being the largest conservation land within a major metropolitan area.

 

And afterward, a pub! Let's head into downtown Quincy, just 6 miles away. There are at least ten pubs & restaurants within about four blocks of each other, centered along Hancock St near Revere Rd. And some of them are quite nice! Maybe we'll try The Fat Cat for some Lobster Mac & Cheese. (24 Chestnut St) Look at these guys! They seem like such nice boys. Who wouldn't want to have a taste of their cheesy lobster mac?! 

And after we eat, there's a great spot nearby to go for a short walk and enjoy views of Boston Harbor - and gorgeous sunsets.

Nut Island comes with an interesting story of environmental disaster and recovery. It even coined a new phrase, the "Nut Island effect" to describe a systemic breakdown in organizational behavior. But we can simply enjoy the views!

And after that, some of us will likely head into Boston for some more revelry...

The Blue Hills were so named by early European explorers who, while sailing along the coastline, noticed the bluish hue on the slopes when viewed from a distance. The blueish color comes from the presence of Riebeckite in the stone.

More than ten thousand years before the Europeans arrived, Native Americans made their home in the these hills. The natives referred to themselves as Massachusett, or "people of the great hills".

Carpool & Directions

Portsmouth Carpool: 10 AM @ Portsmouth Bus Station - 185 Grafton Ave. There are two parking lots. Meet in the back of the overflow lot - the lot farthest from the main bus terminal building, farther up Grafton Ave. Meet at the back of the lot.

Newburyport Carpool: 10:20 AM @ C&J Bus lot, 90 Storey Ave/Rt 113 at I-95. Back of the lot.

Trailhead Directions: I-95 south to I-93 south.
Continue south through Boston.

Continue past the exit for Rt 3, and take I-93 - Exit 5.

Turn Right at ramp to Rt 28 North.

Parking lot is the THIRD one on the left.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment. 

*Unless otherwise specified, refunds for timely cancellations will be processed the day after the event.

*Time and location are subject to change due to weather and other factors.  Always check email & this listing for updates before leaving home.
item.name: Boston's Blue Hills ...and a Beer!
